concept.title: Paragraphs in reference topics
concept.shortdesc: Paragraph (p) elements should not be used in reference topics, as reference topics are intended to contain facts, not ideas.

conbody.p:
Reference topics are designed to contain look-up information, typically
in a tabular form. As such, paragraph elements containing more narrative ideas than look-up data will normally have no place in a reference topic.
The DITA standard does not permit p elements in the body of a reference topic unless contained within elements such as refsyn and section.

Do not use workarounds (such as embedding p elements in sections without titles) in order to include a paragraph. Avoid inserting multiple paragraphs in syntax descriptions (refsyn elements), as these elements are intended to be brief descriptions.
As with other information types, you should avoid using section elements wherever possible.

lq.reftitle: Craig Sandvik, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p:
Yves Barbion wrote: > I see that a

is not permitted in ; it needs to be wrapped in a

. Is there any specific reason for this or is this a bug > in the DTD? It's deliberate. References are expected to have sections right from the beginning, unlike concepts. If you want lead-in text, you still have the ability to include a or .
You can also cheat and omit <title> from the first <section>.
